newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries open lower, profit-taking before GDP.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries open lower, profit-taking before GDP.

text.p: U.S. Treasury price opened moderately lower on Wednesday due to some profit-taking before the government report on first-quarter Gross Domestic Product (GDP), analysts said.

"Profit-taking has left Treasuries slightly lower ... but the declines have been marginal as continued interest in the dollar and gains in European debt markets have provided support," said Kim Rupert, economist at MMS International.
Rupert said before the upcoming data, activity is likely to be cautious.
The market gets a full hand of new economic data during Wednesday's trading session.

The first-quarter preliminary GDP report, due at 0830 EDT/1230 GMT, is expected to be up 4.1 percent, after a 3.8 percent fourth-quarter rise, according to economists polled by Reuters. the GDP price index is expected to be up 2.1 percent after a 1.9 percent rise in the fourth quarter of 1996. And the implicit deflator is expected to be up 1.7 percent after a 1.5 percent rise in the previous quarter.
In early dealings, the 30-year Treasury bond was down 7/32 to 95-9/32, yielding seven percent.

In addition to the GDP report at 0830 EDT, the market will get the April New York NAPM (National Association of Purchasing Management) index at 0900 EDT/1300 GMT, the Chicago PMI (Purchasing Managers Index) at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT.

However, two key reports -- the NAPM (National Association of Purchasing Management's) April survey and the Labor Department's April payroll employment data -- are not due until Thursday and Friday, respectively.
After a "relief" rally ensued on Tuesday on two softer-than-expected economic reports, the market is stationed at the loftiest levels it has been at in a month.
One question is whether the 30-year Treasury bond yield could move below seven percent.

"I think there's enough momentum in this price action that we'll probably hold above 108-16 and test 110 (on the June bond contract) before we see some selling," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at I.D.E.A.
Stiles said the question then would be what to sell -- 10-year notes because of pressure from corporate supply and the upcoming Treasury refunding, or five-year notes.
"You might worry about five years because they outperformed so much yesterday," said Stiles.
Stiles said the bond market could absorb a 3.9 percent or 4.0 percent first-quarter GDP number.
"There's very strong domestic demand," said Stiles. "It's not a bullish number by any means. But the market is aware of first-quarter strength by now."
